doc.headNote: En route to Japan, Margaret Sanger stopped in Hawaii and gave this speech at the M. Lester Dancing academyto several hundred men and women. Judge Sanford B. Doleintroduced her.

docBody.head: Keynote of Social Awakening Is Economically Expedient the Message of Mrs. Sanger
docBody.p: "Birth control is the keynote of a new social awakening - it is not only economically expedient but socially so," said Mrs. Sanger yesterday in her address before several hundred men and women at the M. Lester Dancing academy.

p.q: The speaker was introducted by Judge Sanford B. Dole who said that when people opppose birth control, their opposition is due partly to ignorance, and partly to the fact that people think of quantity, not quality. He also said that the greatest asset a family can have is promising children, while a great misfortune are children with ill health and weak minds.

docBody.p: "The idea of birth control is as old as nature istelf-in fact nature has been and is today the most ruthless advocate of the movement. Our methods of birth control are fairly new and modern and those known today have been used for about 50 years," said Mrs. Sanger.

"Nature's method is that of killing off the unfit, and in this way has kept the population within the means of subsistence, and she has weeded out those unable to compete in life. Nature has by this method perfected types.

"Nature realized that something had to be done to keep the population down. In all countries where they do not allow nature to take its course you find the population question one of great importance.

"When you look out on life today, in every country of the world you find two groups of people. On the first hand there is the small family group made up of men and women who have gone into marriage with understanding and have lmited the numbers of their family according to the health and financial status of the parents. In the great majority of cases you find the children of these families brought to full adult life with all the advantages of education. This group sends their children to the colleges and give their offspring the best condition society has to offer."
"It is not in this group that we find our problem of today, but if we urged them to have larger families they would slide down a grade."

"The other group has perpetuated itself for generations. Mothers have children more often than they can endure to bear them. You find that they are kept in ignorance and the father who is only able to support two children finds himself a family of 10 or 12. In this group you find infant mortality and maternal mortality prevalent, and you find there every problem the first group is trying to solve.
"Our intelligence is unable to cope with the chaotic condition this group has caused. We do everything we can to stop their misery but do nothing to stop their multiplication.

"In the United Statesinfant mortality numbers 300,000 yearly and the majority of these die before they have reached one year of age: they die from poverty and neglect, and still we allow 600,000 parents to remain in ignorance of how to prevent more children from coming into the world.
"Instead of helping these parents not to have any more children we encourage their perpetuation.
"When we take mortality of mothers into consideration we find the condition disgraceful. Many of these mothers pass out of life from preventable causes.

"Then we turn from the tuberculosis question and we find women suffering from heart trouble, kidney trouble and other diseases and it is a crime to allow these women to become mothers. Some of the ideas people of today have are like the old quacks who claimed they could cure cancer by burning off the top - so our charities and welfare organizations are only patching up.
"Parenthood is an international business and it should be made a privilege not an accident."

p.q: In many states objection has been raised towards birth control, but Mrs. Sanger said yesterday that she has never known an argument which could hold against birth control.

docBody.p: "There are a number of objections made against birth control; for instance people always say every new thing is against the laws of God. I will not argue the religious question - if you believe that your conduct is in accordance with the law of your God you must decide the question, but I believe that it is in accord with the law of God to bring creation to a normal condition.
"Another objection raised is that birth control is against the laws of nature. To this we must partly plead guilty and yet almost everything else we do is contrary to nature's laws.
"Many fine things we do are against the laws of nature - civilization means controlling nature for man's highest use.

"Then some people claim it is going to cause race suicide - that if women knew how to control birth there would be no children at all. But I believe that the maternal instinct is one of the deepest things in women, and I do not think that instinct will be thwarted because of knowledge.
